question.title: Will India's central bank's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if India's central bank's preferred inflation measure reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Reserve Bank of India or a relevant Indian government agency and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, The Economic Times). If no such increase is reported during this period, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) Uber lays off at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan, and (b) India's central bank's preferred inflation measure never shows a monthly increase exceeding 0.5%?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: 

(a) Uber confirms the layoff of at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The layoffs must be explicitly linked to the AI-focused reorganization plan announced in 2023. If Uber confirms a lower number of layoffs, or if no such confirmation meeting these criteria is made by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO. Partial layoffs or phased implementations that do not reach the 1,800 employee threshold by the resolution date will also result in a NO resolution.

(b) India's central bank's preferred inflation measure does not report a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The absence of such an increase must be confirmed by the lack of official publications by the Reserve Bank of India or any relevant Indian government agency and not reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, The Economic Times). If any such increase is reported during this period, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame.

Both conditions must be satisfied for this question to resolve as YES; otherwise, it will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) India's central bank's preferred inflation measure shows a monthly increase exceeding 0.5%, or (b) Uber lays off at least 1,800 employees?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) India's central bank's preferred inflation measure reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Reserve Bank of India or a relevant Indian government agency and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, The Economic Times). (b) Uber confirms the layoff of at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The layoffs must be explicitly linked to the AI-focused reorganization plan announced in 2023. If neither of these events occurs by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will Astellas allow generic production of its prostate cancer drug by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Astellas officially announces or confirms that it will allow generic production of its prostate cancer drug, effectively not enforcing its patent. This could be through a formal patent withdrawal, a voluntary license agreement, or any other mechanism that allows for unrestricted generic production. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, statements from relevant regulatory bodies, or reports by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). If no such announcement or confirmation is made by the specified date, or if Astellas continues to enforce its patent rights, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) AstraZeneca allows generic production of its cancer treatment drug, and (b) Astellas prevents generic production of its prostate cancer drug?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (a) AstraZeneca officially announces or confirms that it will allow generic production of its cancer treatment drug, effectively not enforcing its patent. This could be through a formal patent withdrawal, a voluntary license agreement, or any other mechanism that allows for unrestricted generic production. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, statements from relevant regulatory bodies, or reports by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). (b) Astellas does not officially announce or confirm that it will allow generic production of its prostate cancer drug, effectively continuing to enforce its patent. This could be by not withdrawing its patent, not entering into a voluntary license agreement, or any other mechanism that restricts generic production. Confirmation of continued enforcement must come from official company announcements, statements from relevant regulatory bodies, or reports by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). If both conditions are not met by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either Astellas or AstraZeneca allow generic production of their cancer drugs by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, either Astellas or AstraZeneca officially announces or confirms that it will allow generic production of its respective cancer drug, effectively not enforcing its patent. For Astellas, this applies to its prostate cancer drug, and for AstraZeneca, this applies to its cancer treatment drug. This could be through a formal patent withdrawal, a voluntary license agreement, or any other mechanism that allows for unrestricted generic production. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, statements from relevant regulatory bodies, or reports by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). If neither company makes such an announcement or confirmation by the specified date, or if both continue to enforce their patent rights, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the Mexican economy avoid a recession by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Mexican economy does not enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) Sony Corporation resolves a major workers' strike and (b) the Mexican economy enters a recession?
question.body:
(a) Sony Corporation resolves a major workers' strike: This occurs if Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike by July 31, 2024. The strike must involve at least 1,000 workers, last at least one week, and the resolution must be confirmed by official statements from Sony Corporation and the union, and reported by at least two reputable international news sources.

(b) The Mexican economy enters a recession: This occurs if the Mexican economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024, as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) The Mexican economy avoids a recession or (b) Sony Corporation resolves a major workers' strike?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024:

(a) The Mexican economy does not enter a recession. This means there are no two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike by July 31, 2024. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Sony Corporation workers, last for at least one week, and the resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union, and reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If either condition (a) or (b) is met, the question resolves as YES. If neither condition is met, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the European Central Bank announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the European Central Bank officially announces a decrease in its main refinancing operations rate by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the ECB or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Governing Council of the ECB and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual ECB members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) Hyundai Motor Company resolves a major workers' strike (b) The European Central Bank does not announce an interest rate cut?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

(a) Hyundai Motor Company reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike. For this resolution to be valid:
   1. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Hyundai Motor Company workers.
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Hyundai Motor Company and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, this part resolves as NO.

(b) The European Central Bank does not officially announce a decrease in its main refinancing operations rate. The absence of an announcement must be confirmed through the lack of official statements from the ECB or the absence of reports by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must not be a formal decision made by the Governing Council of the ECB and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual ECB members will not count for resolution. If such an official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO.

If both (a) and (b) are satisfied, the question resolves as YES. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) The European Central Bank announces an interest rate cut, or (b) Hyundai Motor Company resolves a major workers' strike?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024:

(a) The European Central Bank officially announces a decrease in its main refinancing operations rate. This must be confirmed through official statements from the ECB or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Governing Council of the ECB and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual ECB members will not count for resolution.

(b) Hyundai Motor Company reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Hyundai Motor Company workers, last for at least one week, and the resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Hyundai Motor Company and the involved union. Additionally, it must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If neither of these events occurs by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's climate disclosure rule be reinstated by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's rule on climate disclosures, previously blocked by a court decision, is reinstated. The reinstatement must be confirmed by official court documents or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The reinstatement could occur through a successful appeal, a reversal of the court's decision, or any other legal mechanism that results in the rule taking effect. If the rule remains blocked or is not reinstated by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The NASDAQ Composite index reaches or exceeds 15,000 points by August 2024, and (b) The U.S. SEC's climate disclosure rule remains blocked by July 2024?
question.body: (a) The NASDAQ Composite index must reach or exceed 15,000 points at any point between October 1, 2023, and August 31, 2024. Intraday highs count, and verification will be based on official reports from sources like Bloomberg, Reuters, or the NASDAQ Stock Market. (b) The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's rule on climate disclosures must remain blocked by July 31, 2024, with no reinstatement confirmed by court documents or reports from at least two major news outlets such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) the U.S. SEC's climate disclosure rule be reinstated by July 2024, or (b) the NASDAQ Composite index reach or exceed 15,000 points by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs: (a) By July 31, 2024, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's rule on climate disclosures, previously blocked by a court decision, is reinstated. This reinstatement must be confirmed by official court documents or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The reinstatement could occur through a successful appeal, a reversal of the court's decision, or any other legal mechanism that results in the rule taking effect. If the rule remains blocked or is not reinstated by the specified date, this part resolves as NO. (b) At any point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, the NASDAQ Composite index reaches or exceeds 15,000 points. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the NASDAQ Stock Market. If the index does not reach 15,000 points during this period, this part resolves as NO. Note that intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 15,000 points.

question.title: Will Samsung announce plans to increase its AI-related workforce by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Samsung publicly announces plans to increase its AI-related workforce. The announcement must be made through official company channels (such as press releases, investor relations statements, or official social media accounts) or reported by at least two major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, Wall Street Journal). The increase in AI-related workforce must be explicitly stated and not inferred from general hiring plans. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, or if Samsung only announces maintaining or decreasing its AI-related workforce, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question is about the announcement of plans, not the actual implementation of those plans.

question.title: Will SAP announce plans to increase its AI-related workforce while Samsung does not by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (a) SAP publicly announces plans to increase its AI-related workforce. The announcement must be made through official company channels (such as press releases, investor relations statements, or official social media accounts) or reported by at least two major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, Wall Street Journal). The increase in AI-related workforce must be explicitly stated and not inferred from general hiring plans. (b) Samsung does not publicly announce plans to increase its AI-related workforce. An announcement must not be made through official company channels (such as press releases, investor relations statements, or official social media accounts) or reported by at least two major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, Wall Street Journal). If Samsung only announces maintaining or decreasing its AI-related workforce, or if no announcement is made by the specified date, this part of the question resolves as YES. Both conditions must be satisfied for the question to resolve as YES. If either SAP does not announce an increase or Samsung does announce an increase, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either Samsung or SAP announce plans to increase their AI-related workforce by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, either Samsung or SAP publicly announces plans to increase their AI-related workforce. For Samsung, the announcement must be made through official company channels (such as press releases, investor relations statements, or official social media accounts) or reported by at least two major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, Wall Street Journal). The increase in Samsung's AI-related workforce must be explicitly stated and not inferred from general hiring plans. For SAP, the announcement must similarly be made through official company channels or reported by at least two major news outlets, with the increase in SAP's AI-related workforce explicitly stated. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, or if either company only announces maintaining or decreasing its AI-related workforce, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question is about the announcement of plans, not the actual implementation of those plans.

question.title: Will the S&P 500 index reach or exceed 4,800 points by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, at any point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, the S&P 500 index reaches or exceeds 4,800 points. The 4,800 point level is chosen as a representative value that the index might have been at before a significant drop. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the New York Stock Exchange. If the index does not reach 4,800 points during this period, the question resolves as NO. Note that intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 4,800 points.

question.title: Will Shopify lay off at least 1,800 employees by July 2024, and will the S&P 500 index fail to reach 4,800 points by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By July 31, 2024, Shopify has confirmed the layoff of at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The layoffs must be explicitly linked to the AI-focused reorganization plan announced in 2023. If Shopify confirms a lower number of layoffs, or if no such confirmation meeting these criteria is made by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO. Partial layoffs or phased implementations that do not reach the 1,800 employee threshold by the resolution date will also result in a NO resolution. (2) At no point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, does the S&P 500 index reach or exceed 4,800 points. The 4,800 point level is chosen as a representative value that the index might have been at before a significant drop. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the New York Stock Exchange. If the index reaches or exceeds 4,800 points during this period, the question resolves as NO. Note that intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 4,800 points. If both conditions are met, the question resolves as YES. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either the S&P 500 index reach or exceed 4,800 points by August 2024, or will Shopify lay off at least 1,800 employees by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs: (a) At any point between October 1, 2023 and August 31, 2024, the S&P 500 index reaches or exceeds 4,800 points. Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the New York Stock Exchange. Intraday highs count for resolution; the index does not need to close at or above 4,800 points. (b) By July 31, 2024, Shopify confirms the layoff of at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal. The layoffs must be explicitly linked to the AI-focused reorganization plan announced in 2023.

question.title: Will the FDA approve MDMA as a therapy for PTSD by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approves MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. For a positive resolution, the approval must be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The approval must specifically be for the use of MDMA in treating PTSD, not for any other condition or use. If no such approval is granted by the resolution date, or if the FDA explicitly rejects or delays the approval beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will Mexican authorities officially declare the dismantling of the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel by July 2024, and will the FDA reject or delay the approval of MDMA as a therapy for PTSD beyond August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: (a) By July 31, 2024, Mexican authorities (such as federal law enforcement agencies or high-ranking government officials) make an official public declaration stating that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or major Mexican news sources) and should indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership structure, operations, or ability to function as a cohesive criminal entity. Mere arrests of individual members or partial disruptions to the cartel's activities do not qualify for a YES resolution. (b) The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) does not officially approve MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. This includes scenarios where the FDA explicitly rejects or delays the approval beyond the resolution date. If the approval is not confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers) for the specific use of MDMA in treating PTSD by the resolution date, the question will resolve as YES. The resolution criteria require that MDMA is not approved for PTSD treatment by the given date. If both conditions are not met, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will either the FDA approve MDMA for PTSD therapy by August 2024, or Mexican authorities declare the dismantling of La Familia Michoacana by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following occurs: (a) The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) officially approves MDMA (3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine) for use as a therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) by August 31, 2024. The approval must be confirmed through an official announcement from the FDA and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers), specifically for the use of MDMA in treating PTSD. (b) Mexican authorities (such as federal law enforcement agencies or high-ranking government officials) make an official public declaration by July 31, 2024, stating that the La Familia Michoacana drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. The declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or major Mexican news sources) and indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's leadership structure, operations, or ability to function as a cohesive criminal entity. If neither of these events occurs by their respective deadlines, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Philippine government enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. If no such enforcement meeting these criteria is confirmed by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (1) The IMF announces new funding commitments totaling over $400 million, and (2) The Philippine government does not enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (1) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases), reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. (2) There are no confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines, meaning either there are no reports by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) or the enforcement does not involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' means less than 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. Alternatively, the shutdown could be due to voluntary closures or economic factors rather than government policy or directive. If both conditions are not met, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Philippine government enforces a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms, or (b) the IMF announces new funding commitments totaling over $400 million?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions is met by July 31, 2024: (a) There are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. (b) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If neither condition is met by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will California conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, California conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a YES resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If no such referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does not qualify for a YES resolution.

question.title: Will Oregon conduct a referendum on abortion rights while California does not by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, both of the following conditions are met:

(a) Oregon officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For this to occur:
   1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Oregon state government.
   2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
   3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

(b) California does not conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For this to occur:
   1. No referendum meeting the specified criteria is officially announced and conducted by the state of California by the specified date.
   2. The primary focus of any conducted referendum is not on abortion rights protection.
   3. No referendum results are publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources meeting the specified criteria.

The question will resolve as NO if either:
- Oregon does not conduct such a referendum by August 31, 2024, or
- California conducts such a referendum by August 31, 2024.

question.title: Will either California or Oregon conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, either California or Oregon conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in their respective states. The criteria for a YES resolution are as follows:

For California:
1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

For Oregon:
1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Oregon state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If either state meets the above criteria by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as YES. If neither state conducts such a referendum by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Central Bank of Israel announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Israel officially announces a decrease in its interest rate by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Central Bank of Israel or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Israel members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) large protests in the United Kingdom in response to healthcare funding cuts, and (b) the Central Bank of Israel not announcing an interest rate cut?
question.body: This combined question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (a) There are credible reports from at least two major international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Al Jazeera) of large protests in the United Kingdom specifically in response to the government's decision to cut healthcare funding. To qualify as 'large', the protests must involve at least 1,000 participants in a single gathering or multiple coordinated gatherings totaling at least 1,000 participants across the United Kingdom. The protests must be explicitly linked to the issue of healthcare funding cuts. If no such protests meeting these criteria occur by the specified date, or if the funding cuts are rescinded before causing such protests, this part will resolve as NO. (b) The Central Bank of Israel does not officially announce a decrease in its interest rate by July 31, 2024. The absence of an announcement must be confirmed by the lack of official statements from the Central Bank of Israel or the absence of reports by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC) about an interest rate cut. The interest rate cut must not be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Israel members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as YES. If both conditions (a) and (b) are satisfied, the combined question resolves as YES; otherwise, it resolves as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) The Central Bank of Israel announces an interest rate cut, or (b) Large protests occur in the UK in response to healthcare funding cuts?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) The Central Bank of Israel officially announces a decrease in its interest rate. This announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Central Bank of Israel or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Monetary Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Israel members will not count for resolution. (b) There are credible reports from at least two major international news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or Al Jazeera) of large protests in the United Kingdom specifically in response to the government's decision to cut healthcare funding. To qualify as 'large', the protests must involve at least 1,000 participants in a single gathering or multiple coordinated gatherings totaling at least 1,000 participants across the United Kingdom. The protests must be explicitly linked to the issue of healthcare funding cuts. If neither (a) nor (b) occurs by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any point during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Nevada maintains its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024, and (b) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage does not exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES only if both of the following conditions are met: (a) As of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, this condition resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law. (b) At no point during August 2024 does the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceed 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate exceeds 5.5% at any point during August 2024, this condition resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must not surpass 5.5%, it can be equal to or less than 5.5%.

question.title: Will either the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceed 5.5% by August 2024, or will Nevada maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following conditions is met: (a) At any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. The rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it. (b) As of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. 'Fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

question.title: Will PepsiCo report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. The increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If no such increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) U.S. weekly jobless claims exceed 200,000 for four consecutive weeks by August 2024, and (b) PepsiCo not report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The number of weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as reported by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceeds 200,000 for four consecutive weeks at any point between now and August 31, 2024. Only official data released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be considered for this condition. (b) By July 31, 2024, PepsiCo does not report an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. This includes scenarios where no such increase is reported, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America. The absence of an increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal. If both conditions are not met, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by mid-2024: an increase in North American demand for Tostitos or U.S. jobless claims exceeding 200,000 for four consecutive weeks?
question.body:
(a) PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 31, 2024, compared to the second quarter of 2023. This must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo, reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If no such increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America, this part will resolve as NO.

(b) The number of weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as reported by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceeds 200,000 for four consecutive weeks at any point between now and August 31, 2024. The question will resolve as NO if this condition is not met within the specified timeframe. Only official data released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be considered.

question.title: Will a court rule on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If no such ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court without a formal ruling, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the court to find the operator liable; it only requires a ruling to be made on the matter of liability.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure shows a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024, and (b) No court rules on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as YES if the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If no such increase is reported during this period, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame. 

(b) This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, no court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. This includes cases where the matter is settled out of court without a formal ruling. If a ruling occurs by the resolution date, documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times), the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the court to find the operator liable; it only requires no ruling to be made on the matter of liability.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by their respective dates: (a) A court ruling on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024, or (b) The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure showing a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if at least one of the following occurs: (a) By August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If no such ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court without a formal ruling, this part resolves as NO. Note that this part does not require the court to find the operator liable; it only requires a ruling to be made on the matter of liability. (b) The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If no such increase is reported during this period, this part resolves as NO. Note that this part focuses on the month-over-month change, not year-over-year or any other time frame.

question.title: Will the Reserve Bank of Australia announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Reserve Bank of Australia officially announces a decrease in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Reserve Bank of Australia or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBA members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the U.S. Education Department implement a plan to offer student loan payment holidays by July 2024 AND will the Reserve Bank of Australia not announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By July 31, 2024, the U.S. Education Department has successfully implemented a plan to offer payment holidays for student loan borrowers. The implementation must be confirmed by official announcements from the U.S. Education Department or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The plan must be a new initiative aimed at offering payment holidays for a significant number of student loan borrowers. If no such implementation occurs by the resolution date, or if the plan is blocked by further legal challenges, this part resolves as NO. (2) The Reserve Bank of Australia does not officially announce a decrease in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The resolution will be based on the absence of any official statements from the Reserve Bank of Australia or reports by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC) confirming a rate cut. If there is no formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting about a rate cut, this part resolves as YES. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBA members will not count for resolution. If an official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO. Only if both (1) and (2) are satisfied will the overall question resolve as YES.

question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following occurs by July 31, 2024: (a) The Reserve Bank of Australia officially announces a decrease in its cash rate target. (b) The U.S. Education Department successfully implements a plan to offer payment holidays for student loan borrowers. The implementation must be confirmed by official announcements from the U.S. Education Department or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The plan must be a new initiative aimed at offering payment holidays for a significant number of student loan borrowers. If neither of these events occurs by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the U.S. Education Department has successfully implemented a plan to defer payments for student loan borrowers. The implementation must be confirmed by official announcements from the U.S. Education Department or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The plan must be a new initiative aimed at deferring payments for a significant number of student loan borrowers. If no such implementation occurs by the resolution date, or if the plan is blocked by further legal challenges, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) New Jersey holds a referendum on abortion rights and (b) the U.S. Education Department does not implement a plan to defer student loan payments?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (a) New Jersey officially conducts a statewide referendum specifically on the topic of enshrining abortion rights in the state constitution. The referendum must be formally announced by the New Jersey state government and verified by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, NPR, or major New Jersey-based news outlets). The referendum must be open to all eligible voters in New Jersey and focus primarily on abortion rights. If no such referendum occurs or is completed by the resolution date, or if the referendum is canceled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO. Note that this part only pertains to the occurrence of the referendum, not its outcome. (b) The U.S. Education Department has not successfully implemented a plan to defer payments for student loan borrowers. This includes scenarios where no official announcements are made by the U.S. Education Department, or no reports are made by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal) confirming the implementation of such a plan. If the plan is blocked by further legal challenges or if no new initiative aimed at deferring payments for a significant number of student loan borrowers is implemented by the resolution date, this part resolves as YES. The overall question resolves as YES if both (a) and (b) resolve as YES.

question.title: Will President Biden deliver a speech at a National Education Association event in Illinois by July 2024?

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the United Food and Commercial Workers endorse a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election, and (b) President Biden not deliver a speech at a National Education Association event in Illinois?

question.title: Will either of the following occur by July 2024: (a) President Biden delivers a speech at a National Education Association event in Illinois, or (b) the United Food and Commercial Workers endorse a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election?

The endorsement must clearly indicate support for a specific candidate in the 2024 presidential race. If neither event occurs by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris announce her running mate at a rally in San Diego by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris publicly announces her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. The announcement must be made by Harris herself during the rally and must clearly identify the individual chosen as her running mate. The event and announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours of the rally. If Harris does not make such an announcement at a San Diego rally by the end of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through other means or at a different location, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by August 2024: (a) the E. coli outbreak tied to beef results in more than 10 confirmed deaths and (b) Kamala Harris does not announce her running mate at a rally in San Diego?
question.body: (a) The E. coli outbreak tied to beef will result in more than 10 confirmed deaths by August 31, 2024. Official reports must confirm these deaths, attributing them to the E. coli outbreak linked to beef from a specific supplier. Confirmation must come from credible sources such as the CDC or equivalent health authorities, and be reported by at least two reputable news outlets. The deaths must be specifically linked to this outbreak and not include deaths from unrelated E. coli cases. (b) By August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris does not publicly announce her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. This includes scenarios where the announcement is not made by Harris herself, is not made during a rally, or is not confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources within 24 hours of the rally.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by August 2024: (a) Kamala Harris announces her running mate at a rally in San Diego, or (b) the E. coli outbreak tied to beef results in more than 10 confirmed deaths?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions is met by August 31, 2024: (a) Vice President Kamala Harris publicly announces her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. If Harris does not make such an announcement at a San Diego rally by the end of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through other means or at a different location, this condition will not be met. (b) There are official reports confirming more than 10 deaths attributed to the E. coli outbreak linked to beef from a specific supplier. Official confirmation must come from credible sources such as the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) or equivalent health authorities, and be reported by at least two reputable news outlets. The death toll must be specifically linked to this outbreak and not include deaths from unrelated E. coli cases. If the death toll remains at 10 or fewer by the resolution date, this condition will not be met. For the purpose of this question, only deaths directly attributed to this specific outbreak will be counted.

question.title: Will Washington maintain its $16 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Washington remains at $16 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Washington state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $16 per hour at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Washington state law.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The average rate on a 30-year mortgage exceeds 7.0% by August 2024, and (b) Washington reduces its $16 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers before July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES only if both of the following conditions are met: (a) At any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 7.0%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. The rate must surpass 7.0%, not merely equal it. (b) At any point before July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Washington is reduced below $16 per hour. The reduction must be confirmed through official Washington state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). 'Fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Washington state law. If either of these conditions is not met, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Washington implement a free community college plan by July 2024, and will the SEIU not endorse any candidate for the 2024 US presidential election by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024: (1) Washington has officially implemented a free community college plan, confirmed by students being able to enroll in community colleges without tuition fees, as reported by at least two reputable news sources. The plan must be state-wide and not limited to specific institutions or pilot programs. (2) The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) has not publicly endorsed any candidate for the 2024 United States presidential election, confirmed by the absence of official SEIU statements or reports by at least two reputable news sources. question.title: Will either the SEIU endorse a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election or Washington implement a free community college plan by July 2024?

Implementation is confirmed if students are able to enroll in community colleges without tuition fees, as reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as local Washington newspapers, national news outlets, or official state government announcements). The plan must be part of a state-wide initiative, not limited to specific institutions or pilot programs. If neither of these events occurs by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Tennessee hold a referendum on labor laws by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the state of Tennessee officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on reforming labor laws in the state. The referendum must be officially announced by the Tennessee Secretary of State or other appropriate state election authority, and must be scheduled to take place on or before August 31, 2024. The referendum question must directly address the issue of labor laws. This question will resolve as NO if no such referendum is officially announced or conducted by the specified date. Note that merely gathering signatures for a potential referendum does not qualify for a YES resolution; the actual referendum must be scheduled or held within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Apple finalize a union contract with store employees in New York by July 2024 (b) Tennessee not hold a referendum on labor laws by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) By July 31, 2024, Apple has finalized and officially signed a collective bargaining contract with the unionized store employees in New York. Confirmation must come from official announcements by Apple, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers' Coalition of Organized Retail Employees, or be reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The contract must be the first of its kind for Apple in the United States. If no such finalization and signing of the contract occurs by the specified date, or if the contract is still in a tentative or non-finalized state, this condition is not met. (b) By August 31, 2024, the state of Tennessee does not officially conduct a public referendum specifically focused on reforming labor laws in the state. The referendum must not be officially announced by the Tennessee Secretary of State or other appropriate state election authority, or must not be scheduled to take place on or before August 31, 2024. The referendum question must not directly address the issue of labor laws. This condition is not met if such a referendum is officially announced or conducted by the specified date. Note that merely gathering signatures for a potential referendum does not qualify for meeting this condition; the actual referendum must be scheduled or held within the specified timeframe. The question resolves as NO if either or both of these conditions are not met.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by their respective deadlines: (a) Tennessee holds a referendum on labor laws, or (b) Apple finalizes a union contract with store employees in New York?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs: (a) By August 31, 2024, the state of Tennessee officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on reforming labor laws in the state. The referendum must be officially announced by the Tennessee Secretary of State or other appropriate state election authority, and must be scheduled to take place on or before August 31, 2024. (b) By July 31, 2024, Apple finalizes and officially signs a collective bargaining contract with the unionized store employees in New York. Confirmation must come from official announcements by Apple, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers' Coalition of Organized Retail Employees, or be reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). The contract must be the first of its kind for Apple in the United States. This resolves as NO if no such finalization and signing of the contract occurs by the specified date, or if the contract is still in a tentative or non-finalized state.

question.title: Will the Bank of Korea announce a reduction in its key interest rate by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Bank of Korea publicly announces a reduction in its key interest rate by August 31, 2024. The announcement must be officially made by the Bank of Korea and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. The reduction must be in the base rate, which is the Bank of Korea's primary tool for influencing the economy. A mere hint or speculation about future rate cuts does not qualify; there must be a concrete announcement of an actual rate reduction. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by August 2024: (1) U.S. weekly jobless claims exceed 275,000 for two consecutive weeks and (2) the Bank of Korea does not announce a reduction in its key interest rate?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by August 31, 2024: (1) The number of weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as reported by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceeds 275,000 for two consecutive weeks at any point between now and August 31, 2024. Only official data released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be considered for this condition. (2) The Bank of Korea does not publicly announce a reduction in its key interest rate by August 31, 2024. The absence of an official announcement by the Bank of Korea regarding a rate reduction, as reported by at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC, will result in this condition being met. The reduction in question pertains to the base rate, which is the Bank of Korea's primary tool for influencing the economy. Speculation or hints about future rate cuts do not count; there must be no concrete announcement of an actual rate reduction by the specified date. The question will resolve as NO if either or both of these conditions are not met within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will either the Bank of Korea announce a reduction in its key interest rate by August 2024, or will U.S. weekly jobless claims exceed 275,000 for two consecutive weeks by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following occurs: (a) The Bank of Korea publicly announces a reduction in its key interest rate by August 31, 2024. The announcement must be officially made by the Bank of Korea and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. A mere hint or speculation about future rate cuts does not qualify; there must be a concrete announcement of an actual rate reduction. (b) The number of weekly initial jobless claims in the United States, as reported by the U.S. Department of Labor, exceeds 275,000 for two consecutive weeks at any point between now and August 31, 2024. This part will resolve as NO if this condition is not met within the specified timeframe. For resolution purposes, only official data released by the U.S. Department of Labor will be considered.

question.title: Will the United Food and Commercial Workers endorse a candidate for the 2024 US presidential election by July 2024?
